author: barnabemonnot
content: another argument for aiming lower than higher is that "legacy" transactions will be cast with their current gas price as the 1559 max fee. the first few blocks could be quite empty then, if most transactions are priced out from the start. though this is probably not a very big deal

author: terra854
content: I would like to clarify, does EIP-1559 burns all the miner fee until the block reward remains at 2 ETH for the remainder of the POW's life? Or is the fee burn has been greatly exaggerated?

author: timbeiko
content: It does not burn all the fees, only the `BASE FEE` miners still get a `TIP` which each transaction. The block reward is untouched. See this article <@!195002499227320321> : https://insights.deribit.com/market-research/establishing-bounds-for-miner-revenue-in-eip-1559/

author: terra854
content: I'm aware about the block reward being untouched, only thing i'm concerned is how the BASEFEE is calculated

author: timbeiko
content: The `BASE FEE` is based on how much gas is used in the previous block

author: timbeiko
content: Blocks can become 200% full (ex: 25m gas if the block gas limit is 12.5m). If they are 0% full, `BASE FEE` drops by 1/8, if they are 100% full, `BASE FEE` stays the same, if they are 200% full, it goes up by 1/8. Linear across the entire range.

author: terra854
content: Are those values set in stone yet?

author: terra854
content: Cause if not, i might suggest loosening the requirements for cutting the BASEFEE as there is almost no way the blocks will be 100% empty

author: terra854
content: Maybe like setting it to 50% full could suffice

author: timbeiko
content: Yes, the values are set in stone

author: timbeiko
content: And there are cases when blocks will be empty: after a sudden rise in the base fee. I recommend reading this paper to get a good intuition: https://timroughgarden.org/papers/eip1559.pdf

author: timbeiko
content: There are a few things that are not perfect with 1559, but mainnet usage data will help inform those changes. Post-merge, we will likely tweak some parameters based on that, but unless there is a major security risk, I don't see us changing the mechanism prior to mainnet launch
